text: When I face a problem, I define it clearly in one sentence before jumping to solutions.
I recognize the difference between what information actually matters and what's just noise or assumption.
When I encounter a complex challenge, I break it down into smaller, manageable parts.
I let problems overwhelm me without pausing to analyze them, and I react instinctively instead of thinking systematically.
When I identify the root cause of a problem, I focus on that instead of treating symptoms.
I recognize when I need to pause and examine data instead of reacting immediately.
When my first approach fails, I explore alternative solutions instead of giving up or repeating the same method.
I get stuck when I don't immediately know the answer, and I avoid difficult problems because they seem too challenging.
When I consider multiple perspectives and see how different parts connect, I understand the full system better.
I recognize the critical constraint that, if removed, would change most of the problem.
When I use mental models or thinking frameworks, I solve problems more systematically and accurately.
I let emotions or assumptions guide my problem-solving instead of separating facts from feelings.
When I think in loops and consider long-term consequences, I see hidden effects that others miss.
I recognize when I need to update my understanding based on new information instead of sticking to old beliefs.
When I learn from past mistakes, I improve my problem-solving approach and avoid repeating errors.
I struggle to see connections between different aspects of a problem, and I focus on surface issues instead of underlying mechanisms.
When I prioritize which problems need immediate attention, I use my time and energy more effectively.
I recognize when I need to adapt my strategy as circumstances change, instead of forcing the same approach.
When I remain calm and focused during difficult problems, I think more clearly and find better solutions.
I give up easily when a problem requires sustained effort, and I avoid taking responsibility for solving problems.
